sentence: A large trader is using options to manage risk in Salesforce.com after takeover speculation drove the software maker to record highs.
optionMONSTER's Heat Seeker monitoring program detected the purchase of 2,500 June 72.50 calls for $5 and the sale of an equal number of June 80 calls for $2.30 yesterday.
Volume surpassed the open interest at both strikes, an indication that new positions were initiated.
Owning calls locks in the price where CRM can be bought, while selling calls forces the investor to deliver shares if a certain level is reached.
Combining the two strategies lets the trader collect the difference between two prices.
(See our Education section for more on vertical spreads .)
Yesterday's trade cost $2.70 to implement and will expand to $7.50 if the stock closes at $80 or higher on expiration--resulting in a potential profit of 178 percent.
It shot to an all-time high of $78.46 in the previous session after Bloomberg reported that the cloud-computing company had been approached by a potential acquirer.
Big players included Oracle, Microsoft, SAP, and International Business Machines were considered potential suitors.
There was also a big rally in late February after strong demand for its web-based products allowed management to raise full-year guidance.
The July call spread will provide the investor with exposure to a potential buyout or another set of good numbers the next time earnings come out on May 20.
It also limits potential losses if CRM is hurt by the recent trend of weakness in high-multiple growth stocks.
Overall option volume was 6 times greater than average, with calls accounting for almost three-quarters of the total.
